TEXT.English: "The glorious sun stays in its course and plays the alchemist. Turning with splendour of his precious eye the meagre earth to glittering gold." - William Shakespeare
TEXT.French: "The glorious sun stays in its course and plays the alchemist. Turning with splendour of his precious eye the meagre earth to glittering gold." - William Shakespeare
TEXT.German: "The glorious sun stays in its course and plays the alchemist. Turning with splendour of his precious eye the meagre earth to glittering gold." - William Shakespeare
TEXT.Italian: "The glorious sun stays in its course and plays the alchemist. Turning with splendour of his precious eye the meagre earth to glittering gold." - William Shakespeare
TEXT.Spanish: "The glorious sun stays in its course and plays the alchemist. Turning with splendour of his precious eye the meagre earth to glittering gold." - William Shakespeare
TEXT.Russian: "The glorious sun stays in its course and plays the alchemist. Turning with splendour of his precious eye the meagre earth to glittering gold." - William Shakespeare

TEXT.English: "We reveal this Book unto thee as an exposition of all things, and a guidance and a mercy to those of you who submit to Allah" - Muhammad, Sura 16.90
TEXT.French: "We reveal this Book unto thee as an exposition of all things, and a guidance and a mercy to those of you who submit to Allah" - Muhammad, Sura 16.90
TEXT.German: "We reveal this Book unto thee as an exposition of all things, and a guidance and a mercy to those of you who submit to Allah" - Muhammad, Sura 16.90
TEXT.Italian: "We reveal this Book unto thee as an exposition of all things, and a guidance and a mercy to those of you who submit to Allah" - Muhammad, Sura 16.90
TEXT.Spanish: "We reveal this Book unto thee as an exposition of all things, and a guidance and a mercy to those of you who submit to Allah" - Muhammad, Sura 16.90
TEXT.Russian: "We reveal this Book unto thee as an exposition of all things, and a guidance and a mercy to those of you who submit to Allah" - Muhammad, Sura 16.90

TEXT.English: "There is no disease that Allah has created, except that He also has created its treatment." - Sunan Abi Dawood
TEXT.French: "There is no disease that Allah has created, except that He also has created its treatment." - Sunan Abi Dawood
TEXT.German: "There is no disease that Allah has created, except that He also has created its treatment." - Sunan Abi Dawood
TEXT.Italian: "Non c'è malattia che Allah abbia creato, senza averne prima creata una cura." - Sunan Abu Dawud
TEXT.Spanish: "There is no disease that Allah has created, except that He also has created its treatment." - Sunan Abi Dawood
TEXT.Russian: "There is no disease that Allah has created, except that He also has created its treatment." - Sunan Abi Dawood

TEXT.English: "It is from their foes, not from their friends, that cities learn the wisdom of building high walls." - Aristophanes
TEXT.French: "Ce sont leurs ennemis et non leurs amis qui ont enseigné aux cités à bâtir de hautes murailles !" - Aristophane
TEXT.German: "Nicht von ihren Freunden, sondern von ihren Feinden lernen Städte, hohe Mauern zu bauen." - Aristophanes
TEXT.Italian: "È dai nemici, non dagli amici, che le città imparano la lezione di costruire alte mura." - Aristofane
TEXT.Spanish: "Es de los enemigos, no de los amigos, que las ciudades aprenden la lección de construir murallas altas." - Aristófanes
TEXT.Russian: "It is from their foes, not from their friends, that cities learn the wisdom of building high walls." - Aristophanes

TEXT.English: "There is nothing which wounds the heart of a noble man more than the thought of his honour being assailed." - Moliere
TEXT.French: "There is nothing which wounds the heart of a noble man more than the thought of his honour being assailed." - Moliere
TEXT.German: "There is nothing which wounds the heart of a noble man more than the thought of his honour being assailed." - Moliere
TEXT.Italian: "Non c'è niente che ferisce di più il cuore di un uomo nobile del solo pensiero che il suo onore possa essere colpito." -Moliere
TEXT.Spanish: "There is nothing which wounds the heart of a noble man more than the thought of his honour being assailed." - Moliere
TEXT.Russian: "There is nothing which wounds the heart of a noble man more than the thought of his honour being assailed." - Moliere

TEXT.English: "All things are in the Universe, and the Universe in all things; we in it and it in us; in this way everything in perfect unity." - Giordano Bruno
TEXT.French: "All things are in the Universe, and the Universe in all things; we in it and it in us; in this way everything in perfect unity." - Giordano Bruno
TEXT.German: "All things are in the Universe, and the Universe in all things; we in it and it in us; in this way everything in perfect unity." - Giordano Bruno
TEXT.Italian: "Tutte le cose sono nell'Universo, e l'Universo è in tutte le cose; noi in lui e lui in noi; in questo modo ogni cosa è in perfetta simbiosi" - Giordano Bruno
TEXT.Spanish: "All things are in the Universe, and the Universe in all things; we in it and it in us; in this way everything in perfect unity." - Giordano Bruno
TEXT.Russian: "All things are in the Universe, and the Universe in all things; we in it and it in us; in this way everything in perfect unity." - Giordano Bruno

TEXT.English: "Astronomy compels the soul to look upwards and leads us from this world to another." - Plato
TEXT.French: "L'astronomie oblige l'âme à se tourner vers les cieux et nous guide de ce monde vers un autre." - Platon
TEXT.German: "Die Astronomie zwingt die Seele, nach oben zu schauen, und führt sie in eine andere Welt." - Plato
TEXT.Italian: "L'astronomia obbliga l'anima a guardare in alto e ci conduce da un mondo a un altro." - Platone
TEXT.Spanish: "La Astronomía obliga al alma a mirar hacia arriba y nos lleva de este mundo a otro." - Platón
TEXT.Russian: "Astronomy compels the soul to look upwards and leads us from this world to another." - Plato

TEXT.English: "Banking establishments are more dangerous than standing armies." - Thomas Jefferson
TEXT.French: "Les établissements bancaires sont plus dangereux qu'une armée en campagne." - Thomas Jefferson
TEXT.German: "Banken sind gefährlicher als stehende Armeen." - Thomas Jefferson
TEXT.Italian: "Gli istituti bancari sono più pericolosi di un esercito sul piede di guerra." - Thomas Jefferson
TEXT.Spanish: "Los bancos son más peligrosos para nuestras libertades que los ejércitos en armas." - Thomas Jefferson
TEXT.Russian: "Banking establishments are more dangerous than standing armies." - Thomas Jefferson

TEXT.English: "In all things of Nature, there is something of the marvellous." - Aristotle
TEXT.French: "In all things of Nature, there is something of the marvellous." - Aristotle
TEXT.German: "In all things of Nature, there is something of the marvellous." - Aristotle
TEXT.Italian: "In tutte le cose della Natura, c'è qualcosa di meraviglioso." - Aristotele
TEXT.Spanish: "In all things of Nature, there is something of the marvellous." - Aristotle
TEXT.Russian: "In all things of Nature, there is something of the marvellous." - Aristotle

TEXT.English: "And them that take up the sword shall perish by the sword" - Book of Matthew, the Bible
TEXT.French: "Et ceux qui auront vécu par l'épée périront par l'épée." - La Bible, Matthieu
TEXT.German: "Wer das Schwert nimmt, der soll durchs Schwert umkommen." - Die Bibel, Matthäus
TEXT.Italian: "Chi di spada ferisce, di spada perisce." - La Bibbia, Matteo
TEXT.Spanish: "Quien toma la espada, a espada morirá." - La Biblia, San Mateo
TEXT.Russian: "And them that take up the sword shall perish by the sword" - Book of Matthew, the Bible

TEXT.English: "It is entirely seemly for a young man killed in battle to lie mangled by the bronze spear. In his death all things appear fair." - Homer
TEXT.French: "Un jeune homme tombé dans la bataille peut afficher la pointe d'airain fichée dans son corps car rien ne choque chez un mort." - Homère
TEXT.German: "So mancher Jüngling fällt in der Schlacht, zermalmt von bronzenem Speer. Im Tode so scheint sein Schicksal vollbracht." - Homer
TEXT.Italian: "Per un giovane è decoroso morire in battaglia trafitto da una lancia di bronzo. Nella morte, tutte le cose sembrano giuste." - Omero
TEXT.Spanish: "Yacer en el suelo, habiendo sido atravesado en la lid por el agudo bronce, es decoroso para un joven, y cuanto de él pueda verse todo es bello, a pesar de la muerte." - Homero
TEXT.Russian: "It is entirely seemly for a young man killed in battle to lie mangled by the bronze spear. In his death all things appear fair." - Homer

TEXT.English: "For everything there is a season and a time for every purpose under heaven." - Ecclisiastics, The Bible
TEXT.French: "A toute chose sa saison, et à toute affaire sous les cieux, son temps." - Le livre de l'Ecclésiaste
TEXT.German: "Für alles gibt es eine Stunde. Und für jedes Vorhaben unter dem Himmel eine Zeit." - Ekklesiastes
TEXT.Italian: "Esistono una stagione e un tempo per ogni cosa." - Ecclesiaste
TEXT.Spanish: "Todo tiene su tiempo, y todo cuanto se hace bajo el sol tiene su hora." - La Biblia, Eclesiastés
TEXT.Russian: "For everything there is a season and a time for every purpose under heaven." - Ecclisiastics, The Bible

TEXT.English: "The glories of our blood and state are shadows not substantial things. There is no armour against fate. Death lays his icy hand on kings." - James Shirley
TEXT.French: "The glories of our blood and state are shadows not substantial things. There is no armour against fate. Death lays his icy hand on kings." - James Shirley
TEXT.German: "The glories of our blood and state are shadows not substantial things. There is no armour against fate. Death lays his icy hand on kings." - James Shirley
TEXT.Italian: "The glories of our blood and state are shadows not substantial things. There is no armour against fate. Death lays his icy hand on kings." - James Shirley
TEXT.Spanish: "The glories of our blood and state are shadows not substantial things. There is no armour against fate. Death lays his icy hand on kings." - James Shirley
TEXT.Russian: "The glories of our blood and state are shadows not substantial things. There is no armour against fate. Death lays his icy hand on kings." - James Shirley

TEXT.English: "We must trust to nothing but facts. These are presented to us by Nature and cannot deceive. We ought in every instance to submit our reasoning to the test of experiment and observation." - Antoine Lavoissier
TEXT.French: "We must trust to nothing but facts. These are presented to us by Nature and cannot deceive. We ought in every instance to submit our reasoning to the test of experiment and observation." - Antoine Lavoissier
TEXT.German: "We must trust to nothing but facts. These are presented to us by Nature and cannot deceive. We ought in every instance to submit our reasoning to the test of experiment and observation." - Antoine Lavoissier
TEXT.Italian: "We must trust to nothing but facts. These are presented to us by Nature and cannot deceive. We ought in every instance to submit our reasoning to the test of experiment and observation." - Antoine Lavoissier
TEXT.Spanish: "We must trust to nothing but facts. These are presented to us by Nature and cannot deceive. We ought in every instance to submit our reasoning to the test of experiment and observation." - Antoine Lavoissier
TEXT.Russian: "We must trust to nothing but facts. These are presented to us by Nature and cannot deceive. We ought in every instance to submit our reasoning to the test of experiment and observation." - Antoine Lavoissier

TEXT.English: "He was a verrey purfit, gentil knight." - Geoffrey Chaucer
TEXT.French: "He was a verrey purfit, gentil knight." - Geoffrey Chaucer
TEXT.German: "He was a verrey purfit, gentil knight." - Geoffrey Chaucer
TEXT.Italian: "Era un cavaliere perfetto, esemplare." - Geoffrey Chaucer
TEXT.Spanish: "He was a verrey purfit, gentil knight." - Geoffrey Chaucer
TEXT.Russian: "He was a verrey purfit, gentil knight." - Geoffrey Chaucer

TEXT.English: "Building well has three conditions; firmness, commodity and delight." - Vitruvius
TEXT.French: "Building well has three conditions; firmness, commodity and delight." - Vitruvius
TEXT.German: "Building well has three conditions; firmness, commodity and delight." - Vitruvius
TEXT.Italian: "Per costruire bene ci vogliono tre cose; stabilità, comodità e diletto." - Vitruvio
TEXT.Spanish: "Building well has three conditions; firmness, commodity and delight." - Vitruvius
TEXT.Russian: "Building well has three conditions; firmness, commodity and delight." - Vitruvius

TEXT.English: "For forms of government let fools contest, whatever's best administered is best." - Alexander Pope
TEXT.French: "For forms of government let fools contest, whatever's best administered is best." - Alexander Pope
TEXT.German: "For forms of government let fools contest, whatever's best administered is best." - Alexander Pope
TEXT.Italian: "Lascia che gli stolti litighino per le forme di governo, la migliore è quella meglio amministrata." - Alexander Pope
TEXT.Spanish: "For forms of government let fools contest, whatever's best administered is best." - Alexander Pope
TEXT.Russian: "For forms of government let fools contest, whatever's best administered is best." - Alexander Pope

TEXT.English: "True knowledge exists in knowing that you know nothing." - Socrates
TEXT.French: "True knowledge exists in knowing that you know nothing." - Socrates
TEXT.German: "True knowledge exists in knowing that you know nothing." - Socrates
TEXT.Italian: "La vera sapienza sta nel sapere di non sapere." - Socrate
TEXT.Spanish: "True knowledge exists in knowing that you know nothing." - Socrates
TEXT.Russian: "True knowledge exists in knowing that you know nothing." - Socrates

TEXT.English: "The wisest men follow their own direction." - Euripides
TEXT.French: "L'homme avisé suit sa propre direction." - Euripide
TEXT.German: "Ein weiser Mann folgt nur sich selbst." - Euripides
TEXT.Italian: "Gli uomini più saggi conoscono la direzione in cui andare." - Euripide
TEXT.Spanish: "Los hombres más sabios siguen su propio rumbo." - Eurípides
TEXT.Russian: "The wisest men follow their own direction." - Euripides

TEXT.English: "Justice is a contract of expediency, entered upon to prevent men harming or being harmed." - Epicurus
TEXT.French: "Justice is a contract of expediency, entered upon to prevent men harming or being harmed." - Epicurus
TEXT.German: "Justice is a contract of expediency, entered upon to prevent men harming or being harmed." - Epicurus
TEXT.Italian: "La giustizia è un contratto di convenienza, creato per impedire agli uomini di nuocere o di essere lesi." - Epicuro
TEXT.Spanish: "Justice is a contract of expediency, entered upon to prevent men harming or being harmed." - Epicurus
TEXT.Russian: "Justice is a contract of expediency, entered upon to prevent men harming or being harmed." - Epicurus

TEXT.English: "Such as do build up their faith upon the holy text of pike and gun...and decide all controversies by infalliable artillery." - Samuel Butler
TEXT.French: "Such as do build up their faith upon the holy text of pike and gun...and decide all controversies by infalliable artillery." - Samuel Butler
TEXT.German: "Such as do build up their faith upon the holy text of pike and gun...and decide all controversies by infalliable artillery." - Samuel Butler
TEXT.Italian: "Such as do build up their faith upon the holy text of pike and gun...and decide all controversies by infalliable artillery." - Samuel Butler
TEXT.Spanish: "Such as do build up their faith upon the holy text of pike and gun...and decide all controversies by infalliable artillery." - Samuel Butler
TEXT.Russian: "Such as do build up their faith upon the holy text of pike and gun...and decide all controversies by infalliable artillery." - Samuel Butler

TEXT.English: "No man shall be taken, imprisoned or destroyed, except by the lawful judgement of his peers." - The Magna Carta
TEXT.French: "Aucun homme libre ne sera saisi, emprisonné ou exécuté, de quelque manière que ce soit, sans un jugement légal de ses pairs." - La Magna Carta
TEXT.German: "Kein freier Mann darf eingesperrt oder bestraft werden ohne ein rechtmäßiges Urteil seiner Standesgenossen." - Magna Carta
TEXT.Italian: "Nessun uomo libero può essere sequestrato, imprigionato o annullato in qualsiasi modo, ma deve essere giudicato solamente per le sue azioni." - La Magna Carta
TEXT.Spanish: "Ningún hombre libre podrá ser detenido o encarcelado o privado de sus derechos de cualquier otra forma, sino en virtud de sentencia judicial de sus pares y con arreglo a la ley del reino." - La Carta Magna
TEXT.Russian: "No man shall be taken, imprisoned or destroyed, except by the lawful judgement of his peers." - The Magna Carta

TEXT.English: "Kings arose before any estates or ranks of men, before any parliaments were holden, or laws made and by then all land was distributed which was at first wholely theirs. So it is that kings are the makers of law, not laws the makers of kings." - James I
TEXT.French: "Kings arose before any estates or ranks of men, before any parliaments were holden, or laws made and by then all land was distributed which was at first wholely theirs. So it is that kings are the makers of law, not laws the makers of kings." - James I
TEXT.German: "Kings arose before any estates or ranks of men, before any parliaments were holden, or laws made and by then all land was distributed which was at first wholely theirs. So it is that kings are the makers of law, not laws the makers of kings." - James I
TEXT.Italian: "I Re c'erano prima di ogni Stato o classe sociale, prima che qualunque parlamento esistesse, o che qualunque legge fosse fatta e dopo essi distribuirono tutta la loro terra. Quindi sono i re a dettare legge, e questa non può imporsi su di essi. " - Giacomo I
TEXT.Spanish: "Kings arose before any estates or ranks of men, before any parliaments were holden, or laws made and by then all land was distributed which was at first wholely theirs. So it is that kings are the makers of law, not laws the makers of kings." - James I
TEXT.Russian: "Kings arose before any estates or ranks of men, before any parliaments were holden, or laws made and by then all land was distributed which was at first wholely theirs. So it is that kings are the makers of law, not laws the makers of kings." - James I

TEXT.English: "All the world's a stage. And all the men and women merely players. They have their exits and their entrances. And each man, in his time, plays many parts." - William Shakespeare
TEXT.French: "Le monde entier est une immense scène ! Tous, hommes et femmes, des acteurs qui y jouent leurs sorties, qui y jouent leurs entrées ; chacun interprète maints rôles dans sa vie !" - William Shakespeare
TEXT.German: "Die ganze Welt ist Bühne. Und alle Frauen und Männer bloße Spieler. Sie treten auf und gehen wieder ab. Sein Leben lang spielt einer manche Rollen." - William Shakespeare
TEXT.Italian: "Il mondo è un palco, uomini e donne sono solamente attori. Ci sono ingressi e uscite e ciascuno può rivestire ruoli diversi. " - William Shakespeare
TEXT.Spanish: "El mundo es un escenario y los hombres y mujeres que lo pueblan son solo actores. Todos hacen entradas y mutis y diversos papeles en la vida. " - William Shakespeare
TEXT.Russian: "All the world's a stage. And all the men and women merely players. They have their exits and their entrances. And each man, in his time, plays many parts." - William Shakespeare

TEXT.English: "The more opportunities there are in a Society for some persons to live upon the toil of others, the less those others may enjoy the fruits of their work themselves." - Anders Chydenius
TEXT.French: "The more opportunities there are in a Society for some persons to live upon the toil of others, the less those others may enjoy the fruits of their work themselves." - Anders Chydenius
TEXT.German: "The more opportunities there are in a Society for some persons to live upon the toil of others, the less those others may enjoy the fruits of their work themselves." - Anders Chydenius
TEXT.Italian: "Più opportunità ci sono nella Società per alcune persone di vivere sul lavoro degli altri, meno questi altri apprezzeranno i frutti del loro lavoro." - Anders Chydenius
TEXT.Spanish: "The more opportunities there are in a Society for some persons to live upon the toil of others, the less those others may enjoy the fruits of their work themselves." - Anders Chydenius
TEXT.Russian: "The more opportunities there are in a Society for some persons to live upon the toil of others, the less those others may enjoy the fruits of their work themselves." - Anders Chydenius

TEXT.English: "There is no wealth like knowledge, no poverty like ignorance." - Caliph Ali ibn Abi-Talib
TEXT.French: "Il n'existe plus grande richesse que le savoir, plus grande pauvreté que l'ignorance." - Ali ibn Abi Talib
TEXT.German: "Wissen ist der größte Reichtum und Ignoranz zeugt von Armut." - Ali ibn Abi-Talib
TEXT.Italian: "La conoscenza è sintomo di benessere, l'ignoranza è sintomo di povertà." - Ali ibn Abi-Talib
TEXT.Spanish: "No hay mayor riqueza que el conocimiento ni mayor pobreza que la ignorancia." - Alí ibn Abi-Talib
TEXT.Russian: "There is no wealth like knowledge, no poverty like ignorance." - Caliph Ali ibn Abi-Talib

TEXT.English: "A designer knows he has achieved perfection, not when there is nothing left to add, but when there is nothing left to take away." - Antoine de Saint-Expury
TEXT.French: "La perfection est atteinte non pas parce qu'il n'y a plus rien à ajouter, mais lorsqu'il n'y a plus rien à retirer." - Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
TEXT.German: "Perfektion ist nicht dann erreicht, wenn es nichts mehr hinzuzufügen gibt, sondern wenn man nichts mehr weglassen kann." - Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
TEXT.Italian: "Un progettista sa di aver raggiunto la perfezione non quando non c'è più niente da aggiungere, ma quando non c'è più nulla da eliminare." - Antoine de Saint-Exupry
TEXT.Spanish: "Un diseñador sabe que ha alcanzado la perfección no cuando ya no tiene nada más que añadir, sino cuando no le queda nada más que quitar." - Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
TEXT.Russian: "A designer knows he has achieved perfection, not when there is nothing left to add, but when there is nothing left to take away." - Antoine de Saint-Expury

TEXT.English: "A desperate disease requires a dangerous remedy." - Guy Fawkes
TEXT.French: "A desperate disease requires a dangerous remedy." - Guy Fawkes
TEXT.German: "A desperate disease requires a dangerous remedy." - Guy Fawkes
TEXT.Italian: "A desperate disease requires a dangerous remedy." - Guy Fawkes
TEXT.Spanish: "A desperate disease requires a dangerous remedy." - Guy Fawkes
TEXT.Russian: "A desperate disease requires a dangerous remedy." - Guy Fawkes

TEXT.English: "For want of a nail the shoe is lost. For want of a shoe the horse is lost. For want of a horse the rider is lost." - George Herbert
TEXT.French: "For want of a nail the shoe is lost. For want of a shoe the horse is lost. For want of a horse the rider is lost." - George Herbert
TEXT.German: "For want of a nail the shoe is lost. For want of a shoe the horse is lost. For want of a horse the rider is lost." - George Herbert
TEXT.Italian: "For want of a nail the shoe is lost. For want of a shoe the horse is lost. For want of a horse the rider is lost." - George Herbert
TEXT.Spanish: "For want of a nail the shoe is lost. For want of a shoe the horse is lost. For want of a horse the rider is lost." - George Herbert
TEXT.Russian: "For want of a nail the shoe is lost. For want of a shoe the horse is lost. For want of a horse the rider is lost." - George Herbert

TEXT.English: "I will to my lord be true, and love all which he loves and shun all which he shuns."- Anglo-Saxon Oath of Fealty
TEXT.French: "I will to my lord be true, and love all which he loves and shun all which he shuns."- Anglo-Saxon Oath of Fealty
TEXT.German: "I will to my lord be true, and love all which he loves and shun all which he shuns."- Anglo-Saxon Oath of Fealty
TEXT.Italian: "I will to my lord be true, and love all which he loves and shun all which he shuns."- Anglo-Saxon Oath of Fealty
TEXT.Spanish: "I will to my lord be true, and love all which he loves and shun all which he shuns."- Anglo-Saxon Oath of Fealty
TEXT.Russian: "I will to my lord be true, and love all which he loves and shun all which he shuns."- Anglo-Saxon Oath of Fealty

TEXT.English: "Wise anger is like fire from a flint. There is a great ado to get it out. And when it does, it is out again immediately." - Mathew Henry
TEXT.French: "Wise anger is like fire from a flint. There is a great ado to get it out. And when it does, it is out again immediately." - Mathew Henry
TEXT.German: "Wise anger is like fire from a flint. There is a great ado to get it out. And when it does, it is out again immediately." - Mathew Henry
TEXT.Italian: "Wise anger is like fire from a flint. There is a great ado to get it out. And when it does, it is out again immediately." - Mathew Henry
TEXT.Spanish: "Wise anger is like fire from a flint. There is a great ado to get it out. And when it does, it is out again immediately." - Mathew Henry
TEXT.Russian: "Wise anger is like fire from a flint. There is a great ado to get it out. And when it does, it is out again immediately." - Mathew Henry

TEXT.English: "Everything is worth what its purchaser will pay for it." - Publius Syrus
TEXT.French: "Toute chose a la valeur que son acquéreur est prêt à payer." - Publius Syrus
TEXT.German: "Jedes Ding ist wert, was der Käufer dafür zahlen will." - Publius Syrus
TEXT.Italian: "Ogni cosa vale il prezzo che un acquirente è disposto a pagare." - Publilio Siro
TEXT.Spanish: "Las cosas valen lo que su comprador esté dispuesto a pagar por ellas." - Publio Siro
TEXT.Russian: "Everything is worth what its purchaser will pay for it." - Publius Syrus

TEXT.English: "I would call architecture frozen music." - Friedrich Schiller
TEXT.French: "I would call architecture frozen music." - Friedrich Schiller
TEXT.German: "I would call architecture frozen music." - Friedrich Schiller
TEXT.Italian: "I would call architecture frozen music." - Friedrich Schiller
TEXT.Spanish: "I would call architecture frozen music." - Friedrich Schiller
TEXT.Russian: "I would call architecture frozen music." - Friedrich Schiller

TEXT.English: "People of the same trade seldom meet together, even for merriment and diversion, but the conversation ends in a conspiracy against the public." - Adam Smith, "The Wealth of Nations"
TEXT.French: "Ceux qui partagent le même métier se réunissent rarement, même pour se divertir, mais leur conversation se fait inévitablement au détriment du public." - Adam Smith
TEXT.German: "Geschäftsleute des gleichen Gewerbes kommen selten, selbst zu Festen und zur Zerstreuung, zusammen, ohne dass das Gespräch in einer Verschwörung gegen die Öffentlichkeit endet." - Adam Smith
TEXT.Italian: "È raro che quelli che fanno lo stesso lavoro si riuniscano, nemmeno per divertirsi o fare baldoria, ma la conversazione termina sempre con una cospirazione ai danni della clientela." - Adam Smith
TEXT.Spanish: "Gente del mismo oficio rara vez se reúne, ni tan solo para alegrarse o divertirse, sin que la conversación termine en una conspiración contra el público." - Adam Smith
TEXT.Russian: "People of the same trade seldom meet together, even for merriment and diversion, but the conversation ends in a conspiracy against the public." - Adam Smith, "The Wealth of Nations"

TEXT.English: "Put your trust in God. And keep your powder dry". - Oliver Cromwell
TEXT.French: "Put your trust in God. And keep your powder dry". - Oliver Cromwell
TEXT.German: "Put your trust in God. And keep your powder dry". - Oliver Cromwell
TEXT.Italian: "Put your trust in God. And keep your powder dry". - Oliver Cromwell
TEXT.Spanish: "Put your trust in God. And keep your powder dry". - Oliver Cromwell
TEXT.Russian: "Put your trust in God. And keep your powder dry". - Oliver Cromwell

TEXT.English: "The Art of Medicine is to amuse the patient while Nature cures the disease." - Voltaire
TEXT.French: "The Art of Medicine is to amuse the patient while Nature cures the disease." - Voltaire
TEXT.German: "The Art of Medicine is to amuse the patient while Nature cures the disease." - Voltaire
TEXT.Italian: "The Art of Medicine is to amuse the patient while Nature cures the disease." - Voltaire
TEXT.Spanish: "The Art of Medicine is to amuse the patient while Nature cures the disease." - Voltaire
TEXT.Russian: "The Art of Medicine is to amuse the patient while Nature cures the disease." - Voltaire

TEXT.English: "There are only two ways of getting on in the world; By one's industry or by the stupidity of others." - Jean de La Bruyere
TEXT.French: "There are only two ways of getting on in the world; By one's industry or by the stupidity of others." - Jean de La Bruyere
TEXT.German: "There are only two ways of getting on in the world; By one's industry or by the stupidity of others." - Jean de La Bruyere
TEXT.Italian: "There are only two ways of getting on in the world; By one's industry or by the stupidity of others." - Jean de La Bruyere
TEXT.Spanish: "There are only two ways of getting on in the world; By one's industry or by the stupidity of others." - Jean de La Bruyere
TEXT.Russian: "There are only two ways of getting on in the world; By one's industry or by the stupidity of others." - Jean de La Bruyere

TEXT.English: "You can't direct the wind, but you can adjust your sails." - unknown
TEXT.French: "On ne peut pas faire tourner le vent, mais on peut faire tourner ses voiles." - Inconnu
TEXT.German: "Den Wind vermagst du nicht zu lenken, deine Segel wohl." - Unbekannt
TEXT.Italian: "Non puoi cambiare la direzione del vento, ma puoi orientare le tue vele." - Sconosciuto
TEXT.Spanish: "No puedes dirigir el viento, pero puedes mover las velas de tu barco." - Proverbio chino
TEXT.Russian: "You can't direct the wind, but you can adjust your sails." - unknown

TEXT.English: "Any society that would give up a little liberty to gain a little security, will deserve neither and lose both." - Benjamin Franklin
TEXT.French: "Une société prête à sacrifier un peu de liberté contre un peu de sécurité ne mérite ni l'une ni l'autre et finit par perdre les deux !" - Benjamin Franklin
TEXT.German: "Eine Gesellschaft, die ihre Freiheit zugunsten der Sicherheit opfert, hat beides nicht verdient." - Benjamin Franklin
TEXT.Italian: "Qualsiasi società che sacrifica un po' di libertà per una maggiore sicurezza non si merita nessuna delle due cose e le perde entrambe." - Benjamin Franklin
TEXT.Spanish: "Cualquier sociedad que renuncie a un poco de libertad para obtener algo de seguridad no se merece ni una ni otra y acabará perdiendo ambas." - Benjamin Franklin
TEXT.Russian: "Any society that would give up a little liberty to gain a little security, will deserve neither and lose both." - Benjamin Franklin

TEXT.English: "Some books are to be tasted, others to be swallowed, and some few to be chewed and digested." - Sir Francis Bacon
TEXT.French: "Certains livres se goûtent, d'autres se dévorent, d'autres encore se mâchent et se digèrent lentement." - Sir Francis Bacon
TEXT.German: "Manche Bücher müssen gekostet werden, manche verschlingt man, und nur einige wenige kaut man und verdaut sie ganz." - Sir Francis Bacon
TEXT.Italian: "Alcuni libri devono essere gustati, altri inghiottiti, altri divorati e digeriti." - Sir Francis Bacon
TEXT.Spanish: "Algunos libros se han de paladear, otros se han de engullir y unos cuantos más se han de masticar y digerir." - Sir Francis Bacon
TEXT.Russian: "Some books are to be tasted, others to be swallowed, and some few to be chewed and digested." - Sir Francis Bacon

TEXT.English: "Man is a tool-using animal. Without tools he is nothing. With tools he is all." - Thomas Carlyle
TEXT.French: "Man is a tool-using animal. Without tools he is nothing. With tools he is all." - Thomas Carlyle
TEXT.German: "Man is a tool-using animal. Without tools he is nothing. With tools he is all." - Thomas Carlyle
TEXT.Italian: "Man is a tool-using animal. Without tools he is nothing. With tools he is all." - Thomas Carlyle
TEXT.Spanish: "Man is a tool-using animal. Without tools he is nothing. With tools he is all." - Thomas Carlyle
TEXT.Russian: "Man is a tool-using animal. Without tools he is nothing. With tools he is all." - Thomas Carlyle

TEXT.English: "It is questionable if all the mechanical inventions yet made have lightened the days toil of any human being." - J.S. Mill
TEXT.French: "It is questionable if all the mechanical inventions yet made have lightened the days toil of any human being." - J.S. Mill
TEXT.German: "It is questionable if all the mechanical inventions yet made have lightened the days toil of any human being." - J.S. Mill
TEXT.Italian: "It is questionable if all the mechanical inventions yet made have lightened the days toil of any human being." - J.S. Mill
TEXT.Spanish: "It is questionable if all the mechanical inventions yet made have lightened the days toil of any human being." - J.S. Mill
TEXT.Russian: "It is questionable if all the mechanical inventions yet made have lightened the days toil of any human being." - J.S. Mill

TEXT.English: "They have shelter and ease in their fine manors. While we have hardship and toil and the rain in the fields. And from us must come from our labour, the things that keep them in luxury." - Jean Froissart
TEXT.French: "They have shelter and ease in their fine manors. While we have hardship and toil and the rain in the fields. And from us must come from our labour, the things that keep them in luxury." - Jean Froissart
TEXT.German: "They have shelter and ease in their fine manors. While we have hardship and toil and the rain in the fields. And from us must come from our labour, the things that keep them in luxury." - Jean Froissart
TEXT.Italian: "They have shelter and ease in their fine manors. While we have hardship and toil and the rain in the fields. And from us must come from our labour, the things that keep them in luxury." - Jean Froissart
TEXT.Spanish: "They have shelter and ease in their fine manors. While we have hardship and toil and the rain in the fields. And from us must come from our labour, the things that keep them in luxury." - Jean Froissart
TEXT.Russian: "They have shelter and ease in their fine manors. While we have hardship and toil and the rain in the fields. And from us must come from our labour, the things that keep them in luxury." - Jean Froissart

TEXT.English: "Like sea discoverers to new worlds have gone, like maps to other worlds have shown. Let us possess one World, each hath one and one for all." - John Donne
TEXT.French: "Like sea discoverers to new worlds have gone, like maps to other worlds have shown. Let us possess one World, each hath one and one for all." - John Donne
TEXT.German: "Like sea discoverers to new worlds have gone, like maps to other worlds have shown. Let us possess one World, each hath one and one for all." - John Donne
TEXT.Italian: "Like sea discoverers to new worlds have gone, like maps to other worlds have shown. Let us possess one World, each hath one and one for all." - John Donne
TEXT.Spanish: "Like sea discoverers to new worlds have gone, like maps to other worlds have shown. Let us possess one World, each hath one and one for all." - John Donne
TEXT.Russian: "Like sea discoverers to new worlds have gone, like maps to other worlds have shown. Let us possess one World, each hath one and one for all." - John Donne

TEXT.English: "As to diseases make a habit of two things - to help, or at least, to do no harm." - Hippocrates
TEXT.French: "Il faut s'exercer, dans le domaine des maladies, à deux choses : être utile, sinon ne pas nuire." - Hippocrate
TEXT.German: "Was Krankheiten betrifft, so hat man zwei Möglichkeiten: zu heilen oder wenigstens nicht zu schaden." - Hippokrates
TEXT.Italian: "Per debellare le malattie ci vogliono cose in grado di aiutare o, al massimo, non nuocere." - Ippocrate
TEXT.Spanish: "En cuanto a las enfermedades, ten por costumbre dos cosas: ayudar o, al menos, no hacer más daño." - Hipócrates
TEXT.Russian: "As to diseases make a habit of two things - to help, or at least, to do no harm." - Hippocrates

TEXT.English: "One minute decides the outcome of a battle, one hour the outcome of a campaign, and one day the fate of empires." - Alexander Suvorov
TEXT.French: "One minute decides the outcome of a battle, one hour the outcome of a campaign, and one day the fate of empires." - Alexander Suvorov
TEXT.German: "One minute decides the outcome of a battle, one hour the outcome of a campaign, and one day the fate of empires." - Alexander Suvorov
TEXT.Italian: "One minute decides the outcome of a battle, one hour the outcome of a campaign, and one day the fate of empires." - Alexander Suvorov
TEXT.Spanish: "One minute decides the outcome of a battle, one hour the outcome of a campaign, and one day the fate of empires." - Alexander Suvorov
TEXT.Russian: "One minute decides the outcome of a battle, one hour the outcome of a campaign, and one day the fate of empires." - Alexander Suvorov

TEXT.English: "Diplomacy without armies is like music without instruments." - Frederick the Great
TEXT.French: "Diplomacy without armies is like music without instruments." - Frederick the Great
TEXT.German: "Diplomacy without armies is like music without instruments." - Frederick the Great
TEXT.Italian: "Diplomacy without armies is like music without instruments." - Frederick the Great
TEXT.Spanish: "Diplomacy without armies is like music without instruments." - Frederick the Great
TEXT.Russian: "Diplomacy without armies is like music without instruments." - Frederick the Great

TEXT.English: "Meditation is the life of the soul, action is the soul of meditation, so meditate that you mayst give God glory." - Francis Quarles
TEXT.French: "Meditation is the life of the soul, action is the soul of meditation, so meditate that you mayst give God glory." - Francis Quarles
TEXT.German: "Meditation is the life of the soul, action is the soul of meditation, so meditate that you mayst give God glory." - Francis Quarles
TEXT.Italian: "Meditation is the life of the soul, action is the soul of meditation, so meditate that you mayst give God glory." - Francis Quarles
TEXT.Spanish: "Meditation is the life of the soul, action is the soul of meditation, so meditate that you mayst give God glory." - Francis Quarles
TEXT.Russian: "Meditation is the life of the soul, action is the soul of meditation, so meditate that you mayst give God glory." - Francis Quarles

TEXT.English: "The monuments of wit survive the monuments of power." - Francis Bacon
TEXT.French: "The monuments of wit survive the monuments of power." - Francis Bacon
TEXT.German: "The monuments of wit survive the monuments of power." - Francis Bacon
TEXT.Italian: "The monuments of wit survive the monuments of power." - Francis Bacon
TEXT.Spanish: "The monuments of wit survive the monuments of power." - Francis Bacon
TEXT.Russian: "The monuments of wit survive the monuments of power." - Francis Bacon

TEXT.English: "If music be the food of love, play on." - William Shakespeare
TEXT.French: "Si la musique nourrit l'amour, alors jouez !" - William Shakespeare
TEXT.German: "Wenn Musik die Nahrung der Liebe ist, so spielt fort." - William Shakespeare
TEXT.Italian: "Se la musica è il nutrimento dell'amore, continua a suonare." - William Shakespeare
TEXT.Spanish: "Si la música es el alimento del amor, tocadla." - William Shakespeare
TEXT.Russian: "If music be the food of love, play on." - William Shakespeare

TEXT.English: "Such is the human condition, that to wish greatness for one's country is to wish harm to another's." - Voltaire
TEXT.French: "Such is the human condition, that to wish greatness for one's country is to wish harm to another's." - Voltaire
TEXT.German: "Such is the human condition, that to wish greatness for one's country is to wish harm to another's." - Voltaire
TEXT.Italian: "Such is the human condition, that to wish greatness for one's country is to wish harm to another's." - Voltaire
TEXT.Spanish: "Such is the human condition, that to wish greatness for one's country is to wish harm to another's." - Voltaire
TEXT.Russian: "Such is the human condition, that to wish greatness for one's country is to wish harm to another's." - Voltaire

TEXT.English: "The royal navy hath ever been its greatest defence and ornament. It is its ancient and natural strength, the floating bulwarks of our island." - William Blackstone
TEXT.French: "The royal navy hath ever been its greatest defence and ornament. It is its ancient and natural strength, the floating bulwarks of our island." - William Blackstone
TEXT.German: "The royal navy hath ever been its greatest defence and ornament. It is its ancient and natural strength, the floating bulwarks of our island." - William Blackstone
TEXT.Italian: "The royal navy hath ever been its greatest defence and ornament. It is its ancient and natural strength, the floating bulwarks of our island." - William Blackstone
TEXT.Spanish: "The royal navy hath ever been its greatest defence and ornament. It is its ancient and natural strength, the floating bulwarks of our island." - William Blackstone
TEXT.Russian: "The royal navy hath ever been its greatest defence and ornament. It is its ancient and natural strength, the floating bulwarks of our island." - William Blackstone

TEXT.English: "We should distinguish the properties of particulars, and gather by induction what pertains to the eye when vision takes place; And what is found in the manner of sensation to be uniform, unchanging, manifest and not subject to doubt." - Ibn al-Haytham
TEXT.French: "We should distinguish the properties of particulars, and gather by induction what pertains to the eye when vision takes place; And what is found in the manner of sensation to be uniform, unchanging, manifest and not subject to doubt." - Ibn al-Haytham
TEXT.German: "We should distinguish the properties of particulars, and gather by induction what pertains to the eye when vision takes place; And what is found in the manner of sensation to be uniform, unchanging, manifest and not subject to doubt." - Ibn al-Haytham
TEXT.Italian: "We should distinguish the properties of particulars, and gather by induction what pertains to the eye when vision takes place; And what is found in the manner of sensation to be uniform, unchanging, manifest and not subject to doubt." - Ibn al-Haytham
TEXT.Spanish: "We should distinguish the properties of particulars, and gather by induction what pertains to the eye when vision takes place; And what is found in the manner of sensation to be uniform, unchanging, manifest and not subject to doubt." - Ibn al-Haytham
TEXT.Russian: "We should distinguish the properties of particulars, and gather by induction what pertains to the eye when vision takes place; And what is found in the manner of sensation to be uniform, unchanging, manifest and not subject to doubt." - Ibn al-Haytham

TEXT.English: "You philosophers are lucky men. You write on paper. And paper is patient. But I am an Empress. And the people are not." - Catherine the Great
TEXT.French: "You philosophers are lucky men. You write on paper. And paper is patient. But I am an Empress. And the people are not." - Catherine the Great
TEXT.German: "Ihr Philosophen habt Glück. Ihr schreibt auf Papier. Und Papier ist geduldig. Ich bin eine Kaiserin. Und das Volk ist es nicht." - Katharina die Große
TEXT.Italian: "You philosophers are lucky men. You write on paper. And paper is patient. But I am an Empress. And the people are not." - Catherine the Great
TEXT.Spanish: "You philosophers are lucky men. You write on paper. And paper is patient. But I am an Empress. And the people are not." - Catherine the Great
TEXT.Russian: "You philosophers are lucky men. You write on paper. And paper is patient. But I am an Empress. And the people are not." - Catherine the Great

TEXT.English: "Patron (n.) One who countenances, supports or protects. Commonly a wretch who supports with insolence and is repaid with flattery." - Samuel Johnson
TEXT.French: "Patron (n.) One who countenances, supports or protects. Commonly a wretch who supports with insolence and is repaid with flattery." - Samuel Johnson
TEXT.German: "Patron (n.) One who countenances, supports or protects. Commonly a wretch who supports with insolence and is repaid with flattery." - Samuel Johnson
TEXT.Italian: "Patron (n.) One who countenances, supports or protects. Commonly a wretch who supports with insolence and is repaid with flattery." - Samuel Johnson
TEXT.Spanish: "Patron (n.) One who countenances, supports or protects. Commonly a wretch who supports with insolence and is repaid with flattery." - Samuel Johnson
TEXT.Russian: "Patron (n.) One who countenances, supports or protects. Commonly a wretch who supports with insolence and is repaid with flattery." - Samuel Johnson

TEXT.English: "I have gained this by philosophy, that I do without being commanded what others do only from the fear of the law." - Aristotle
TEXT.French: "La philosophie m'a appris ceci : ce que je fais sans que l'on me l'ordonne, les autres le font par crainte de la loi." - Aristote
TEXT.German: "Dies habe ich durch Philosophie gewonnen. Dass ich tue, ohne befohlen zu werden, was andere nur aus Furcht vor dem Gesetz tun." - Aristoteles
TEXT.Italian: "Con la filosofia ho conquistato il diritto di fare ciò che voglio senza essere comandato da chi lo fa solo per timore della legge." - Aristotele
TEXT.Spanish: "Con la filosofía he logrado lo siguiente: hacer, sin que me lo ordenen, lo que otros hacen solamente por temor a la ley." - Aristóteles
TEXT.Russian: "I have gained this by philosophy, that I do without being commanded what others do only from the fear of the law." - Aristotle

TEXT.English: "To every action there is always an opposed but equal reaction." - Isaac Newton
TEXT.French: "A chaque action correspond une réaction égale." - Isaac Newton
TEXT.German: "Jede Aktion erzeugt gleichzeitig eine Reaktion." - Isaac Newton
TEXT.Italian: "Ad ogni azione, corrisponde una reazione uguale ma di segno opposto." - Isaac Newton
TEXT.Spanish: "Para cada acción existe siempre una reacción igual y de sentido contrario." - Isaac Newton
TEXT.Russian: "To every action there is always an opposed but equal reaction." - Isaac Newton

TEXT.English: "You should hammer your iron when it is glowing hot." - Publius Syrus
TEXT.French: "Il faut battre le fer tant qu'il est chaud." - Publius Syrus
TEXT.German: "Man muss das Eisen schmieden, solange es heiß ist." - Publius Syrus
TEXT.Italian: "Dovresti battere il ferro finché è caldo." - Publilio Siro
TEXT.Spanish: "Debes golpear el hierro cuando aún está al rojo vivo." - Publio Siro
TEXT.Russian: "You should hammer your iron when it is glowing hot." - Publius Syrus

TEXT.English: "The house of everyone is to him his castle and fortress...as well for his defence against injury and violence as for his repose." - Edward Coke
TEXT.French: "The house of everyone is to him his castle and fortress...as well for his defence against injury and violence as for his repose." - Edward Coke
TEXT.German: "Mein Haus ist meine Burg." - Edward Coke
TEXT.Italian: "The house of everyone is to him his castle and fortress...as well for his defence against injury and violence as for his repose." - Edward Coke
TEXT.Spanish: "The house of everyone is to him his castle and fortress...as well for his defence against injury and violence as for his repose." - Edward Coke
TEXT.Russian: "The house of everyone is to him his castle and fortress...as well for his defence against injury and violence as for his repose." - Edward Coke

TEXT.English: "Good order and discipline in an army are more to be depended upon than mere ferocity." - Nicolo Machiavelli
TEXT.French: "Good order and discipline in an army are more to be depended upon than mere ferocity." - Nicolo Machiavelli
TEXT.German: "Eine Armee hängt mehr von Ordnung und Disziplin ab als von reiner Grausamkeit." - Nicolo Machiavelli
TEXT.Italian: "Good order and discipline in an army are more to be depended upon than mere ferocity." - Nicolo Machiavelli
TEXT.Spanish: "Good order and discipline in an army are more to be depended upon than mere ferocity." - Nicolo Machiavelli
TEXT.Russian: "Good order and discipline in an army are more to be depended upon than mere ferocity." - Nicolo Machiavelli

TEXT.English: "The city will gain beauty worthy of its name and to you it will be useful for its revenues and the eternal flame of its aggrandizement." - Leonardo Da Vinci
TEXT.French: "The city will gain beauty worthy of its name and to you it will be useful for its revenues and the eternal flame of its aggrandizement." - Leonardo Da Vinci
TEXT.German: "The city will gain beauty worthy of its name and to you it will be useful for its revenues and the eternal flame of its aggrandizement." - Leonardo Da Vinci
TEXT.Italian: "The city will gain beauty worthy of its name and to you it will be useful for its revenues and the eternal flame of its aggrandizement." - Leonardo Da Vinci
TEXT.Spanish: "The city will gain beauty worthy of its name and to you it will be useful for its revenues and the eternal flame of its aggrandizement." - Leonardo Da Vinci
TEXT.Russian: "The city will gain beauty worthy of its name and to you it will be useful for its revenues and the eternal flame of its aggrandizement." - Leonardo Da Vinci

TEXT.English: "The true work of Art is but a shadow of the Divine Perfection." - Michelangelo
TEXT.French: "The true work of Art is but a shadow of the Divine Perfection." - Michelangelo
TEXT.German: "Die wahre Arbeit der Kunst ist nur ein Schatten göttlicher Perfektion." - Michelangelo
TEXT.Italian: "The true work of Art is but a shadow of the Divine Perfection." - Michelangelo
TEXT.Spanish: "The true work of Art is but a shadow of the Divine Perfection." - Michelangelo
TEXT.Russian: "The true work of Art is but a shadow of the Divine Perfection." - Michelangelo

TEXT.English: "I saw the angel in the marble and carved until I set him free." - Michelangelo
TEXT.French: "I saw the angel in the marble and carved until I set him free." - Michelangelo
TEXT.German: "Ich sah den Engel im Marmorblock und hämmerte bis er befreit war." - Michelangelo
TEXT.Italian: "I saw the angel in the marble and carved until I set him free." - Michelangelo
TEXT.Spanish: "I saw the angel in the marble and carved until I set him free." - Michelangelo
TEXT.Russian: "I saw the angel in the marble and carved until I set him free." - Michelangelo

TEXT.English: "True knowledge is greater than the sum of its parts." - Aristotle
TEXT.French: "La totalité est plus que la somme des parties." - Aristote
TEXT.German: "Das Ganze ist größer als die Summe seiner Teile." - Aristoteles
TEXT.Italian: "Il risultato è migliore della somma delle sue parti." - Aristotele
TEXT.Spanish: "Un todo es más que la suma de sus partes." - Aristóteles
TEXT.Russian: "True knowledge is greater than the sum of its parts." - Aristotle

TEXT.English: "Man is born free but everywhere he is in chains." - Jean Jacques Rousseau
TEXT.French: "Man is born free but everywhere he is in chains." - Jean Jacques Rousseau
TEXT.German: "Der Mensch wird frei geboren, und überall ist er in Banden." - Jean Jacques Rousseau
TEXT.Italian: "Man is born free but everywhere he is in chains." - Jean Jacques Rousseau
TEXT.Spanish: "Man is born free but everywhere he is in chains." - Jean Jacques Rousseau
TEXT.Russian: "Man is born free but everywhere he is in chains." - Jean Jacques Rousseau

TEXT.English: "I do not feel obliged to believe that the same God who endowed us with sense, reason and intellect has intended us to forgoe its use." - Galileo Galilei
TEXT.French: "J'ai du mal à croire que le même Dieu qui nous a dotés d'esprit, de raison et d'intelligence puisse vouloir que nous y renoncions." - Galilée
TEXT.German: "Ich fühle mich nicht zu dem Glauben verpflichtet, dass derselbe Gott, der uns mit Sinnen, Vernunft und Verstand ausgestattet hat, von uns verlangt, dieselben nicht zu benutzen." - Galileo Galilei
TEXT.Italian: "Non sono obbligato a credere che lo stesso Dio che ci ha donato il senso, la ragione e l'intelligenza voleva che ne dimenticassimo l_uso." - Galileo Galilei
TEXT.Spanish: "No me siento obligado a creer que el mismo Dios que nos ha dotado de sentido común, raciocinio e intelecto tuviera como intención privarnos de su uso." - Galileo Galilei
TEXT.Russian: "I do not feel obliged to believe that the same God who endowed us with sense, reason and intellect has intended us to forgoe its use." - Galileo Galilei

TEXT.English: "Is this the face that launched a thousand ships?" - Christopher Marlowe
TEXT.French: "Is this the face that launched a thousand ships?" - Christopher Marlowe
TEXT.German: "Is this the face that launched a thousand ships?" - Christopher Marlowe
TEXT.Italian: "Is this the face that launched a thousand ships?" - Christopher Marlowe
TEXT.Spanish: "Is this the face that launched a thousand ships?" - Christopher Marlowe
TEXT.Russian: "Is this the face that launched a thousand ships?" - Christopher Marlowe

TEXT.English: "And forty winters shall besiege thy brow, And dig deep trenches in the beauty's field. Against the wrackful siege of battering day. When rocks impregnable are not so stout." - William Shakespeare
TEXT.French: "And forty winters shall besiege thy brow, And dig deep trenches in the beauty's field. Against the wrackful siege of battering day. When rocks impregnable are not so stout." - William Shakespeare
TEXT.German: "And forty winters shall besiege thy brow, And dig deep trenches in the beauty's field. Against the wrackful siege of battering day. When rocks impregnable are not so stout." - William Shakespeare
TEXT.Italian: "And forty winters shall besiege thy brow, And dig deep trenches in the beauty's field. Against the wrackful siege of battering day. When rocks impregnable are not so stout." - William Shakespeare
TEXT.Spanish: "And forty winters shall besiege thy brow, And dig deep trenches in the beauty's field. Against the wrackful siege of battering day. When rocks impregnable are not so stout." - William Shakespeare
TEXT.Russian: "And forty winters shall besiege thy brow, And dig deep trenches in the beauty's field. Against the wrackful siege of battering day. When rocks impregnable are not so stout." - William Shakespeare

TEXT.English: "Wit's an unruly engine, wildly striking sometimes a friend, sometimes the engineer." - George Herbert
TEXT.French: "Wit's an unruly engine, wildly striking sometimes a friend, sometimes the engineer." - George Herbert
TEXT.German: "Wit's an unruly engine, wildly striking sometimes a friend, sometimes the engineer." - George Herbert
TEXT.Italian: "Wit's an unruly engine, wildly striking sometimes a friend, sometimes the engineer." - George Herbert
TEXT.Spanish: "Wit's an unruly engine, wildly striking sometimes a friend, sometimes the engineer." - George Herbert
TEXT.Russian: "Wit's an unruly engine, wildly striking sometimes a friend, sometimes the engineer." - George Herbert

TEXT.English: "If you speak the truth, have a foot in the stirrup." - Turkish proverb
TEXT.French: "Si tu dis vrai, mets le pied à l'étrier." - Proverbe turc
TEXT.German: "Wer die Wahrheit spricht, sollte besser einen Fuß im Steigbügel haben." - Arabisches Sprichwort
TEXT.Italian: "Se dici il vero, metti un piede nella staffa." - Proverbio Turco
TEXT.Spanish: "Si dices la verdad, ya tienes un pie en el estribo." - Proverbio turco
TEXT.Russian: "If you speak the truth, have a foot in the stirrup." - Turkish proverb

TEXT.English: "Two cities have been formed by two loves, the earthly by love of self, the heavenly by the love of God." - St. Augustine
TEXT.French: "Deux amours ont fait deux cités : l'amour de soi, la cité terrestre ; l'amour de Dieu, la cité céleste." - Saint-Augustin
TEXT.German: "Es gibt zwei Städte auf der Welt. Die eine ist auf der Liebe zu sich selbst, die andere auf der Liebe zu Gott errichtet." - Augustinus
TEXT.Italian: "Esistono due tipi di città, fondate su due tipi d'amore: quello terreno per sé stessi e quello celeste per di Dio." - Sant'Agostino
TEXT.Spanish: "Dos amores han fundado dos ciudades: el amor a uno mismo, la terrenal; y el amor a Dios, la celestial." - San Agustín
TEXT.Russian: "Two cities have been formed by two loves, the earthly by love of self, the heavenly by the love of God." - St. Augustine

TEXT.English: "Our wants are various, and nobody has been found able to acquire even the necessaries without the aid of other peoples. And there is scarcely any Nation that has not stood in the need of others." - Anders Chydenius
TEXT.French: "Our wants are various, and nobody has been found able to acquire even the necessaries without the aid of other peoples. And there is scarcely any Nation that has not stood in the need of others." - Anders Chydenius
TEXT.German: "Our wants are various, and nobody has been found able to acquire even the necessaries without the aid of other peoples. And there is scarcely any Nation that has not stood in the need of others." - Anders Chydenius
TEXT.Italian: "Our wants are various, and nobody has been found able to acquire even the necessaries without the aid of other peoples. And there is scarcely any Nation that has not stood in the need of others." - Anders Chydenius
TEXT.Spanish: "Our wants are various, and nobody has been found able to acquire even the necessaries without the aid of other peoples. And there is scarcely any Nation that has not stood in the need of others." - Anders Chydenius
TEXT.Russian: "Our wants are various, and nobody has been found able to acquire even the necessaries without the aid of other peoples. And there is scarcely any Nation that has not stood in the need of others." - Anders Chydenius

TEXT.English: "As the King lives, so shall his vassals." - Old Portugese proverb
TEXT.French: "As the King lives, so shall his vassals." - Old Portugese proverb
TEXT.German: "As the King lives, so shall his vassals." - Old Portugese proverb
TEXT.Italian: "As the King lives, so shall his vassals." - Old Portugese proverb
TEXT.Spanish: "As the King lives, so shall his vassals." - Old Portugese proverb
TEXT.Russian: "As the King lives, so shall his vassals." - Old Portugese proverb

TEXT.English: "Heavens gates are not so highly arched as prince's palaces, that they enter there must go upon their knees." - John Webster
TEXT.French: "Heavens gates are not so highly arched as prince's palaces, that they enter there must go upon their knees." - John Webster
TEXT.German: "Heavens gates are not so highly arched as prince's palaces, that they enter there must go upon their knees." - John Webster
TEXT.Italian: "Heavens gates are not so highly arched as prince's palaces, that they enter there must go upon their knees." - John Webster
TEXT.Spanish: "Heavens gates are not so highly arched as prince's palaces, that they enter there must go upon their knees." - John Webster
TEXT.Russian: "Heavens gates are not so highly arched as prince's palaces, that they enter there must go upon their knees." - John Webster

TEXT.English: "He who first shortened the labour of copyists by device of moveable type was disbanding hired armies and creating a whole democratic world through the art of the printing machine." - Thomas Carlyle
TEXT.French: "He who first shortened the labour of copyists by device of moveable type was disbanding hired armies and creating a whole democratic world through the art of the printing machine." - Thomas Carlyle
TEXT.German: "He who first shortened the labour of copyists by device of moveable type was disbanding hired armies and creating a whole democratic world through the art of the printing machine." - Thomas Carlyle
